utterances: President Putin is KGB and this and that.
You know what?
Putin's fine.
He's fine.
We're all fine.
We're people.
So what can you tell us about their upcoming meeting in Helsinki?

Well, one thing that the upcoming meeting between President Trump and Vladimir Putin is causing is our allies in NATO to be very worried that he will have a contentious meeting with them and then go off to Helsinki and heap praise on Vladimir Putin, not unlike the way he did after the contentious G-7 meeting.
And then he held a summit with North Korea's Kim Jong Un, who he praised repeatedly.
That's NPR national political correspondent Mara Liasson.

Actor and comedian David Alan Grier made a name for himself as part of the ensemble cast of the 1990's show ""In Living Color."" Grier's character Antoine Merryweather in the ""Men on Film"" sketch is a classic.
(Soundbite of ""Men on Film"" sketch from ""In Living Color"")
(As Antoine Merryweather) Now, I'd like to talk about a film I've been anxiously waiting to see, ""Great Balls of Fire.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(As Blaine Edwards) I ain't gonna touch it.
But the title alone gets two snaps up.

David Alan Grier is back, as the host of Comedy Central's ""Chocolate News."" It's a fake news magazine show, from a black perceptive, that spoofs everything and everyone, including imagining Maya Angelou, doing a new inaugural poem.
(Soundbite of TV show ""Chocolate News"")
(As Maya Angelou) I christen you Hosanna Obama.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(As Maya Angelou) Brown Bama, Dark Angel, Black Knight.
I pronounce you prince, king, pharaoh.
Obama, as your spiritual mama, I bid you good morning, good afternoon, good evening and sweet dreams.
Happy birthday, Mr. President.
Freedom!
(Soundbite of laughter)
(As Maya Angelou) And then they release the dogs.
So if you had to describe ""Chocolate News"" to someone who doesn't understand black culture and doesn't watch TV, what would it be?
It's like fake, black news.
If Tavis Smiley had a really great sense of humor.

It also pokes fun at all of those for black people shows that we've all seen, that were - used to be mandated by the federal government in order to - on public television, you'd see them, usually around three or four in the morning.
(Soundbite of laughter)
In order to fulfill their urban minority quota.
Positively black.
It's like our job is to find the blackness in any and everything, and we search for it.
Dr. Maya Angelou.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah.
You go all the way there.
Do you expect a team of thug poets to come beat you up any time?
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, they'll laugh.
But it seemed to fit so much in with what we're going through right now, that that was a way to be political, to talk about the atmosphere surrounding the election, and to do it in a unique way.
All right, speaking of the election.
If Senator John McCain wins, will there be an audience for ""Chocolate News?"" Or will ""Chocolate"" be...
Of course there will.
Of course there will.
Who do you see as the audience for this show?
Everyone, everyone.
The conceit of the show is in the title and the concept.
That's like saying, was Dave Chappelle's show only for black people?
Of course not.
Was ""In Living Color"" only for black people?
No. It was just - both of those shows were done from the sensibility of the creators, who happened to African-American.
Of course it was weird.
It was you.
But I can't - I'm envisioning you with the ""Men On Film"" haircut right now.
So that's...
...And part-time MBA student, as well.
Exactly.
She did get really good at the game and beat it.
And, years later, they were long-distance.
And he gave her an electric can opener.
Very practical, which, like a lot of gifts, can be practical...
(Laughter).
...But she doesn't cook.
And she said she never used it.
One of the things I liked about your piece is that you explain why gift-giving tends to be so fraught.
Why is it, like, such a thing?

I think, sometimes, when couples are still getting to know each other, they take that gift as, like, a proxy for how deep someone's feelings are, how much you mean to them and kind of also how much the other person is paying attention to you.
What do you like to do?
What are your interests?
Is it possible that somebody could be very thoughtful, but they express it in terms of, like, everyday kindnesses, like always having the coffee made...
For sure.
...As opposed to buying something, you know?
One thing that a lot of these matchmakers and relationship experts mentioned to me was that love languages can come into play.
Do you know about the five love languages?
Tell us about that.
Yeah, talk about that...
So there are acts of service, words of affirmation, gift-giving can be one way that people show love, physical touch and quality time.
Let's say my love language is quality time, and I also love words of affirmation, right?
So I might really appreciate it if someone wrote me a poem or took me out on a daylong journey rather than a gift.
And so, sometimes, I think gift givers don't always know, what is my recipient's love language?
And I'm dying to know what happened with the electric can opener.
It sat in her kitchen for a long time.
And then, her husband got it in the divorce.
Ouch.
That's Lisa Bonos.
She writes the Relationships blog for The Washington Post and writes other articles about relationships.
Thanks so much for joining us.
Thanks for having me.
